children.subject: I am planning on taking 189 next sem, and I am currently in 126. If you look at shewchucks hmwk from last semester, there is a very obvious weeder hmwk (either 1 or 2) that seems to involve a lot of probability and linalg. It is meant to see if you are prepared to learn the topics. I think he doesn't spend much time going over these topics, and they are recommended courses to take, so I would adequately prepare. I would love to hear from someone who has taken the class as well.

^ I took Shewchuk's 189 last spring. The weeder hw is hw 2, you can take a look at it over here: https://people.eecs.berkeley.edu/~jrs/189/hw/hw2.pdf For what it's worth, I came into 189 without 126 (only cs 70) and had taken 127 (but hated it and didn't understand any of it very well) and got an A in the class. I think having a solid probability/linear algebra (I did math 54) background is very necessary, but it doesn't necessarily need to be from 126/127.

for your question:  how much probability knowledge can I take away from 189?

In my opinion, you will probably get good at doing probability problems, but 126 is a really great class that focuses on the probability theory itself. 189 is application of what you learn in 126 / 70 (CLT, Variance, idk, just probability concepts in general), but since you will be using those probability concepts in application, you probably won't focus / learn the theory behind them, such as proving them or connecting the concepts together and just getting really good at them. I wouldn't say 189 is a probability course.

history.content: in 189 you apply probability and its a tool, you don't really learn as much as it is expected you know it. If you want to learn probability well take 126, but you can succeed in 189 witout it especially if you're willing to study the concepts you don't know

Hi! I am in a situation that I may not be able to take both 126 and 189 since I also need to do job-hunting. So I am wondering, if I only take 189, then how much probability knowledge can I learn from it? Will Shewchuk's 189 also cover some probability materials as in 126?


Thank you so much! (My question is actually that how much probability knowledge can I take away from 189, instead of how 189 will go without probability knowledge from 126. But any input is appreciated!)
history.subject: How much 126 materials are covered in 189?

history.content:
